div.head: Question 3
Whether Christians are bound to obey secular princes
div.p: QUESTION THREE Whether Christians are bound to obey secular princes
THIRD, it is asked whether Christians are bound to obey secular princes,

and it seems that they are not because James 1 the evangelical law is called
the law of perfect liberty , which would not be the case, unless it freed them from obedience to any secular prince, therefore, etc.

Likewise anyone can lawfully resort to the judgment of one to whom he is bound to obey, but it is not lawful for Christians to resort to the judgment of secular princes especially if they are unbelievers. Whence
the Apostle reproves in I Corinthians 6
certain ones who resorted to judges who were secular unbelievers, therefore it seems that Christians are not bound to obey secular princes, especially if they are unbelievers.

ON THE CONTRARY is what
the Apostle says in Romans 13
that
every soul should be subject to the higher powers , and that he speaks of secular power, is clear from what is added: for he does not bear the sword in vain. But it is established that he speaks to Christians; to whom he also writes, therefore Christians are bound to obey secular power.

RESPONSE. Among secular princes some are believers, and some are unbelievers, and the question will be addressed in both cases using one general principle known in itself, namely this, that if a Christian is legitimately subject to secular power certainly he is bound to obey in those matters to which the power extends not only for the sake of wrath, that is, fear of punishment, but for the sake of conscience, because by not obeying
he resists the ordinance of God , as is said
in Romans 13 . First therefore it will be shown that Christians are legitimately subject to believing secular power. And second it will be inquired whether they are legitimately subject to unbelieving secular power.

The first is clear in two ways: first thus, that which is according to the dictate of right reason is not removed by faith and grace, for faith and grace do not destroy nature or natural reason, but perfect them, but secular authority ought according to the dictate of right reason to exist among men, as is clear from the preceding question, therefore this is not removed from Christians by faith and grace, by which they are distinguished from others. Likewise wherever the order of justice can be disturbed, it is fitting that there be some who by their office make this order to be observed, but among Christians the order of justice happens to be disturbed, not only in spiritual matters, but also in temporal matters, therefore it is fitting that there be some who by their office make this order to be observed among Christians, but one has this by office only if he who presides, whence
in Romans 13
Do you wish not to fear the power, do good, and you will have praise from it . But if you do evil, fear: for he does not bear the sword in vain, for he is a minister of God, etc. Therefore it is fitting according to right reason, that among Christians there be some who preside not only in spiritual matters (such as ecclesiastical prelates) but also in temporal matters, and these are secular princes. It is clear therefore that secular power among Christians is legitimate, to which subjects are bound to obey in those things which pertain to the right of such power.

As for the second question whether an unbelieving secular prince can rightly preside over believing Christians, and consequently whether Christians ought to obey him. A distinction must be made because the dominion or relation of an unbelieving prince over a Christian either preexists the distinction between them by faith and unbelief, for instance, because the subject was converted to the faith and not the prince, as in the primitive church commonly happened, or a slave is converted and not the master, as still sometimes happens with slaves of Jews, or such authority or dominion is newly introduced. In the first case some say that the distinction of believers from unbelievers does not remove ipso facto the preceding authority or dominion of unbelievers over believers. The reason for this is, because divine right which is from grace does not remove human right which is from natural reason, but authority was introduced by human right and rests on natural reason, as was shown above. But the distinction of believers from unbelievers is from divine right, therefore this distinction does not remove the preceding authority, or dominion ipso facto, indeed believing subjects are still bound to obey unbelieving princes or masters, but they add that although ipso facto such domination is not removed, it can however justly be removed by the ordinance of the church, which has the authority of God, because unbelievers by merit of their unbelief deserve to lose power over believers who are transferred into the sons of God, and this indeed the church sometimes does, and sometimes does not do. In those unbelievers who temporally are subject to the church, and in its members this right the church establishes, so that the slave of Jews made a Christian is immediately freed from servitude if he was a home-born slave, that is, born in servitude, and similarly if he was bought for servitude. But if he was bought for trade he is required to be offered for sale within three months, as is clear
57 dist.
fraternitatem
and
extra de Iudaeis et Sara. cap. 1
and
the last , nor in this does the church do them injury, because since Jews are servants of the church, it can dispose of their goods, just as also secular princes have issued many laws toward their subjects in favor of liberty. But in those unbelievers who temporally are not subject to the church or its members the aforesaid right it does not establish, although it could justly establish it, and this it does to avoid scandal just as also the Lord
in Matthew 17
showed that he could excuse himself from tribute, because the sons are free, but he commanded the tribute to be paid to avoid scandal.

But I consider the first of these absolutely true, namely that a subject of an unbelieving prince if he is converted to the faith is not ipso facto absolved from the dominion of another, but what is added, that justly by the ordinance of the church having the authority of God he can be absolved, because unbelievers by merit of their unbelief can justly be deprived of the power which they have over believers is indeed true, provided however that something is added namely this that if the prince or unbelieving master not content with his legitimate authority strives to reduce his subject or slave made a Christian to unbelief, nor allows him to be quiet as before, but harasses him by insults offered to the creator then ipso facto he is deprived or at least can be deprived by the authority of the church of the right which he had over his subject.

This is clear by reason and by analogy. The reason is as follows: an inferior lord procuring and persuading secession from the superior lord from whom he has all authority to rule is deprived ipso facto or justly deserves to be deprived of the authority of his principate or dominion, but an unbelieving prince or master who strives to recall to unbelief his subject or slave made a Christian and to harass him by insults offered to the creator is of this kind, for he urges secession from God from whom all power comes as is said
in Romans thirteen , therefore such a one justly deserves to be deprived of the authority of his dominion. The same is clear by analogy, for equally great is the obligation of spouses to each other as is that of a subject to a prince or slave to a master, but if one of the spouses is converted to the faith while the other remains in unbelief if the unbeliever does not wish to remain with the believer except by drawing him to unbelief, or with blasphemy of the creator, the believer is absolved from the bond by which he was bound to him, in the same way if an unbelieving prince or master strives to reduce a slave or subject made a Christian to unbelief by blaspheming the creator, he deserves to lose the right of dominion which he has over him, whence also in this case Christians move by authority of the church a just war against unbelievers lest they impede the faith of Christ by blasphemies or evil persuasions or manifest persecutions, and perhaps this cause the church has, even now and has long had with respect to anyone converted to the faith with respect to any unbelieving prince or master whether Saracen or Jew, because since they are obstinate in their unbelief it is probable, and has been found by many experiments that any subject or slave of theirs converted to the faith they would strive to reduce to unbelief and therefore this condition is held by the church as fulfilled

But if an unbelieving prince or master were content with his legitimate authority, nor would strive to reduce his subject to unbelief, nor bring blasphemies against the creator, but would permit him to be quiet as before, it does not so evidently appear that such a prince ought justly to be deprived of the authority and dominion which he previously had over his subject, because if a subject is newly converted to the faith and not the master, in this there is no new sin of the master, but it is the merit of the subject, therefore the unbelief of the master cannot be a sufficient reason why he should deserve to lose the dominion which he previously legitimately had while existing in the same unbelief, but if there is any reason it ought to be taken from the merit of the slave or subject, who has been newly transferred into the society of the sons of God. And for this reason it could seem to someone that such a one deserves to be absolved from the dominion of the unbelieving prince, and the church by the authority of God could justly absolve him. But although one converted to the faith deserves something greater than such liberty (for he is freed from sin and deserves eternal life) nevertheless it is not necessary that he deserve to be freed from subjection to the unbelieving prince, because one converted to the faith by this alone does not deserve to be freed from that which in no way prejudices the faith, but to be subject to an unbelieving prince who is content with his legitimate authority, nor strives to reduce his subject converted to the faith to unbelief, nor harasses him by any insult offered to the creator, but allows him to be quiet as before, does not prejudice, nor in any way derogate from the faith, therefore from conversion to the faith alone one does not deserve to be absolved from such subjection. The church also although it has on earth the authority of God, that authority however does not exceed the limitation of Scripture. But Scripture expressly states that those converted to the faith ought to be subject to their former masters, although unbelievers, and to obey them. For
the Apostle says in Romans thirteen
that the princes who at that time were only unbelievers are ministers of God
serving for the praise of the good and vengeance of evildoers, for which reason tributes are given to them, and he concludes,
render therefore to all their dues: to whom tribute is due, tribute; to whom custom is due, custom , whence it is clear that he commands those converted to the faith still to be subject to unbelieving princes and to render those things which by reason of subjection are due to them: and
in the second chapter of First Peter
it is said,
be subject whether to the king, as excelling, or to governors as sent by him for the punishment of evildoers, and the praise of the good , because so is the will of God: and
in the sixth chapter of First Timothy
it is said thus
whosoever are under the yoke as slaves, let them count their masters worthy of all honor , and he speaks of unbelieving masters, as is clear from what is immediately added there. From which it is clear that Scripture does not suggest that slaves or subjects converted to the faith can or ought by the merit alone of their conversion to be absolved from the power of their masters, although unbelievers: indeed it rather seems to insinuate the opposite

Second this is urged thus, it is illicit that unbelievers who never received the faith should be compelled to the faith, but if the church would deprive an unbelieving prince of his right which he has over his subjects when they are converted to the faith, then it would compel them to the faith by the loss of their goods, because a slave is the property of his master, and every subject is in some way bound to his lord, this the master would lose, unless he were converted to the faith, just as the slaves or subjects, therefore it is illicit to do this: but no power exists for illicit things, therefore, etc.

Third thus, if one of the spouses is converted to the faith while the other remains in unbelief, if the unbeliever consents to dwell with the believer without drawing him to unbelief; and without blasphemy of the creator the bond of matrimony between them is not dissolved, nor ought to be dissolved, therefore similarly if an unbelieving prince or master requires from a subject or slave made a Christian only that which pertains to the right of his dominion, nor strives to draw him to unbelief, nor harasses him by blasphemies offered to the creator, the obligation which previously existed of the slave to his master or of the subject to his prince is not dissolved, nor can it justly be dissolved. However as was said before, the aforesaid condition perhaps at present does not hold, nor has it long held because of the obstinacy of unbelievers, because of which they strive to blaspheme the creator, and to reduce believers to unbelief, for which reason it is prohibited for a spouse converted to the faith to remain with one who remains in unbelief, as is stated
in the twenty-sixth question 1. chapter on the Jew at the end : and
chapter saepe malorum consortia , and in many other places. And therefore the aforesaid condition is now held as null and the opposite is supposed as fulfilled: for which reason the doctors say that a slave or subject converted to the faith can by the church be absolved from the dominion and power of an unbelieving prince. But I think that this is on the supposition of the condition stated above. Thus therefore it is clear how Christians are bound to obey unbelieving masters, when the dominion preexists the distinction between them by faith and unbelief.

But concerning the authority of unbelievers newly to be introduced over believers in no way does the church permit that unbelievers acquire dominion over believers, or that they be placed over them in any office, and reasonably so. For this tends to scandal and danger to the faith: for easily those who are subjected to the jurisdiction of others are changed by it, as is clear in the books of Kings in many places. For unbelievers despise the faith when they recognize the defects of believers, because of which the church prohibits that such dominion be introduced, but if it has been introduced, as certain Christian princes make from Jews certain overseers and bailiffs, they sin indeed by acting against the statute of the church. But subjects are nevertheless bound to obey Jews thus appointed in those things which pertain to the just execution of the office committed to them.

TO THE FIRST argument to the contrary
it must be said that the evangelical law is called the law of perfect liberty because it frees from the servitude of sin, which is the worst servitude, and from every old law which scarcely anyone could ever bear: and not because it frees from civil servitude by which a subject is bound to obey his master, since this is consonant with reason, and meritorious.

To the second argument
it must be said that the major premise is false. For to obey a prince in those things which pertain to such dominion is necessary, but to bring another to judgment before an unbelieving judge is voluntary, and therefore the first is obligatory but the second is not, but merely voluntary: whence where it tends to danger it is illicit, in which case the Apostle speaks. But what the Lord says
in Matthew 17
the sons are free
speaking of himself, he says this, for he was the son of the eternal king, as
Peter had said before in the sixteenth chapter
You are the Christ the son of the living God , and therefore he was free from the obligation of tribute, but it is not so with us nor was it so then with the other believers of that time. For the Lord commanded them to pay tributes to the unbelieving prince,
in the twenty-second chapter of Matthew
saying,
Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's .
